Posts.Content: Hi Gem Welcome to the club. This is a great place to be at time like this, I don't know what I'd have done without  the support of the lovely people on here since I was diagnosed with IDC in February. I was grade 1, stage 1/2 with lymph node involvement so I had a lumpectomy and now I'm mid way through chemotherapy with radiotherapy and hormones to follow. It's bewildering at the beginning, and as Skye says, it's a terrible shock but it gets easier, once you get a treatment plan in place and you know your team.  I wish you all the best for the next few weeks, take one day at a time and come here whenever you need to.  Love Sarah
Posts.Title: I have just been diagnosed with invasive ductual carcinoma stage 2...

Posts.Content: Ah ok, I didn't read the instructions because I had the booklet from the clinic which said once a day, oh well, if they drop off it won't be the fault of the Evonail!! You're right, everything takes ages - I normally forget my Evonail until I get into bed and then you have to wait for it to dry so I'm sitting there for what seems like an eternity wafting my hands around.  Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Evonail, again

Posts.Content: Hi Jan I'm only putting on one coat a day, at night which was the advice given by my chemo nurse, but I know others have been told 2 coats. It's true it does take some getting off after a week, I suppose because there are 7 (in your case 14) coats of the stuff. I put a blob of remover on each nail, massage it in and then leave it for a few minutes, this seems to do the trick although I sometimes have to repeat this process. I had painful index finger nails just after my first tax and was a bit worried but it's gone away and they seem ok, so fingers crossed. Love Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Evonail, again

Posts.Content: HI Hannah Glad you're feeling better about it, I still have the odd moment of rage, especially as the holiday date approaches, but now I'm well and truly stuck into treatment, it's no longer at the forefront.  My treatment has been a mixed bag so far, the first chemo session was fine and the side effects were nasty for about 24 hours and then manageable. My problem now is a low white cell count and we've just had to revise our "reserve" holiday plans (10 days back in the uk) because my 2nd chemo has been delayed. But I'm certainly not frightened of the chemo any more. I'm on sick leave from work, I'm an English teacher and I'm paid for the hours I'm actually in class so I'm getting state sick pay which in France is half normal pay -  or at least I will be when they sort it out -  I'm complicated because my hours are variable and I actually have 3 different employers. I worked before and after surgery, in fact I went straight from class to the clinic for my op and then back to work 2 days after coming out - but it was hard and I probably overdid it. Our insurance is with Staysure and they are being very slow. I never thought of Saga because I always thought of it for over 50s and I'm not actually 50 yet although my husband is, so when, hopefully we get paid for the cancellation and can rebook for next year (fingers crossed) I'll look at Saga. The start of treatment for me was an enormous relief, so hope you feel the same, just look after yourself and listen to your body. Sarahxxxx
Posts.Title: Cancelling Holidays is the Pits.

Posts.Content: Consultant has drained about half a litre of lymph from my armpit. Feels so much better. He says I can go any time I need to because it probably will need doing again. What a relief!!
Posts.Title: Haematoma

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my WLE nearly 2 weeks ago and have developed a haematoma under my armpit. It seems to be getting worse rather than better, it's stopping me from holding my arm against my side as it's quite painful which is giving me a pain in the shoulder as I'm holding myself awkwardly, it's also making it difficult to sleep as I can't get comfortable at night. I saw my GP on Friday who said that the body would reabsorb it with time but I think it's got bigger since then. I see my consultant on Friday morning so I was going to wait until then to ask about it but it's getting me down a bit. Does anyone else have experience of this, particularly at what point it should be drained. Everything is healing nicely, but this is making me quite tired and irritable. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Haematoma

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia and Tilly Being in France I don't have a bc nurse, just my consultant and gp. I did ring the consultant yesterday afternoon and his secretary said to ring back this morning so I'm going to see what he says. So fingers crossed he'll do something about it.  xxx
Posts.Title: Haematoma

Posts.Content: Ouch ouch ouch!!!! Particularly the wound stabbing bit. What an ordeal on top of everything else. Sarahxxxx
Posts.Title: Haematoma

Posts.Content: My cousin sent me this article last night and it made me feel angry, given the importance of positive thinking it's incredibly negative but I read on for the advice and then the advice given is not something that most people would be able to follow which then adds guilt to the normal emotional ups and downs we are experiencing (i.e. am I doing everything to make this easier for myself). I feel anything but dead, I feel fantastically alive and grateful that this treatment is going to give me the best chance of getting better. The article actually made me feel (momentarily) negative which I've generally not been at all.  Losing your hair is hard, but it feels harder before you actually lose it than after, once it's gone, for me at least, it was a big relief,  as for the real Russian lady hair stick on wig, the cost is beyond most people and frankly I can't imagine not being able to rip my wig off my head in relief (in front of the mirror and my family - who cares - I like my bald head and my family love me) when I get back from the shops - it gets hot here in the summer.  I also find that sleeping with a bald head has resolved some of the hot flushes I was getting. And then fasting for 4 days before chemo - I for one couldn't do this - I'm already losing too much weight  - I know not everyone is actually sick (I was, very), but  dry heaving isn't a pleasant experience - my onco nurse urged me to eat the lunch they gave me during chemo for this very reason. Anyway, this is just my tuppence worth. Good luck with the start of your chemo Liz, I was terrified before mine but it was a lot better than I had imagined. See you in June chemo club. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Hi Hannah I so know how you feel. Last September I booked our holiday of a lifetime for my 50th Birthday - 3 weeks in Sri Lanka leaving on 9th July. I was diagnosed in February and at first everyone was saying I'd just need radiotherapy so the holiday would be ok. Anyway despite being low grade and caught early the cancer had progressed to my nodes and so finally it was decided that I would need chemo. It's heartbreaking isn't it??, unravelling the little piece of happiness that you have planned so blissfully and thought about for months. I had a work promotion in September with lots of extra responsibilities, so the holiday was also a reward after what I knew would be a tough year (didn't know how tough at that point). Anyway, like you - a lot of crying, spitting and shouting - was actually hoping the tear stains on my insurance forms would encourage the insurers to deal with it more quickly. You will feel better about it when your treatment starts. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Cancelling Holidays is the Pits.

Posts.Content: Hi Skye I've just come across this thread and I feel so angry. Whilst I can't actually add anything constructive to the excellent  advice and support already given, I just wanted to say I hope it went well today and I'm thinking about you. I can't imagine coping with all this with a baby and then having to contend with so much selfishness from those who should be falling over themselves to help you. Lots of love, Sarahxx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Oh Skye, I don't know what to say, it's just unbelievable, perhaps it's time to take a step back and cut them out of you life a bit, you really don't need this. As Julia says, the stares are normal and from my own experience, I think they bother you more when you're feeling down (everyone has the odd off day). I'm sometimes tempted to whip my scarf off and pull a face at people, but I haven't done it yet, perhaps after the end of chemo champagne when I have some Dutch courage!! You're so near the end of chemo now, just over 3 weeks and you'll have had your last one, I know it's hard but try and keep that thought. Lots of love Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Support issues (again/still!!!)

Posts.Content: Hi Sally Lou I can't add much to what everyone else has said. The shock and uncertainty on diagnosis was the worst bit for me. I was diagnosed in February and I've now nearly finished chemo, my cancer is a known quantity so I know exactly what needs to be done to fight it, I can get on with it and look forward to the end,which is in sight. This forum helped enormously in those early days and continues to do so now. It's bound to be hard for your family but I think it's important that you open up to them and let them help you all they can, they will get some comfort from being able to support and help you along the way and you will need them too emotionally and practically. It's great to have someone to celebrate the good days and get through the bad days with.  The twinge thing is very normal, even after having every inch of my body scanned, I still worry irrationally about every little twinge, but these days it tends to be a fleeting worry rather than a keep me up all night worry fest. Anyway, try to take each day as it comes and keep your lovely family close, Love, Sarahxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz I'm an English teacher, but I work in the private sector, so I don't know whether the scarf will be an issue, we are affiliated to Education Nationale for some of the classes so it may be a problem, I hadn't really thought about it. I told my employers before I started my chemo as I went on sick leave (I'm salaried) so they know but maybe I should ask about the scarf. I also hate my wig, it's hot, scratchy and just not me, don't know quite what I'll do if I'm not allowed to wear my scarves. I also am planning to go back in September so maybe I'll just go back and see what happens. I've been very open about my breast cancer from the beginning, I live in a small town and see colleagues and students all the time, I didn't want them to see me looking so different and be shocked, I'd rather tell everyone myself than have people find out by word of mouth.  I've had a lot of support and understanding which has helped, I wouldn't say that people have treated me differently I would confide in your contact and explain your worries, see what her take on it is, at least that way you'll know now and maybe have a bit of support at work.  Lots of love, Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Women in France - scarves in schools

Posts.Content: Like Karen I'm in France and the Portacath is standard and as she says, it is absolutely no trouble, it occasionally sets off alarms in supermarkets (this has happened to me once) but they give you a little card to keep in your purse to show people. Mine was fitted under local anaesthetic but it was no problem, I had a real giggle with the surgeon as he wanted an English lesson and I was high on the oxygen. I've never had blood taken through it as I go to the laboratory for my pre-chemo blood test and it's done in the normal way but then I don't have a vein problem. Sarahxx
Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: I have a complete love/hate relationship with my wig, It suits ok in terms of style and colour and sometimes I feel really good in it but other times I don't feel like myself at all. Yesterday was a bad day but it was very hot so that didn't help. I actually quite like my bald head but can't quite pluck up the courage to go out with nothing on.  The wig fitting was very quick and I hated it, I chose the 3rd wig she plonked on my head, it's right for colour and style but I always liked to stick my hair behind my ears and tie it back and now it has to be over my ears. It's also complicated with sunglasses - yesterday I put my sunglasses under the wig so that they could go behind my ears but then when I went to pull them off it almost dislodged the wig.Also find it difficult not to fiddle with it all the time. The French system is about as generous as the one in the UK it seems - I got 120 euros towards mine and the total cost was around 330 euros (and that was a cheapie). Having grumbled though it's nice to have it for an evening out, so I don't regret getting it at all. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Rage at the Wigs!

Posts.Content: It's sometimes hard to tell people, I'm salaried but I have 2 employers, I only have a cdd with the one which provides most of my work, so I was worried that they would not renew my contacts for next year, but  everyone has been very supportive and they've been happy to let me plan minimal lessons for September so I can start back properly in October, I've also had a lot of support from colleagues and everyone has tried to help, so it's been a huge weight off my mind.  I do think good mother tongue English teachers can be hard to find and it can take a long time to built up a rapport with the students, so I'm sure all your clients will feel the same and do everything they can to help you ease back into it.  Love Sarah
Posts.Title: Women in France - scarves in schools

Posts.Content: The panel finally met on monday to discuss my treatment. I had a small 8mm tumour successfully removed from my left breast at the beginning of March. Unfortunately there were a few cells in one lymph node and my surgeon told me that the panel may decide on chemo based on this. I got the decision this afternoon and it's chemo but I'm also being send for a scintigraphy on Friday morning. Does anyone have any idea why I might be being sent for this? I've Googled a bit and it seems to be another diagnostic test but I don't know why they're giving it to me so I'm getting in a bit of a stew about it (thought we'd finished with all the diagnostic stuff and that it was just treatment from now on). Can anyone shed any light on it. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Hi Helen They don't tend to offer the oncotype dx test in France. I've been reading, fatal I know, but I think it's because I've got very dense breast tissue and it will show up any areas (even the tiniest ones) in the breast which are hard to see by other means, I think they are wondering why I had cells in my node when the tumour is very small, non-aggressive and contained - no-one expected it to be in my node. I have to go for an injection of radioactive stuff at 8am and then return 3 hours later for the scan. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn It was actually a bone scan, I think there are different sorts of scintigraphy, but mine was intended to detect abnormal bone growth which tends to happen when there are metastases. Found out yesterday that it was clear so big relief. Yeah I thought I'd get away with it- I'm still harbouring a tiny little hope that after the scintigraphy result they'll change their minds but it really is a teeny hope so I going to wait a bit longer to cancel the holiday, just in case. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: I've finally managed to do this Carolyn. I'm not sure what second and third mean in the chemo row but it doesn't seem to change anything. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Well I've had my radioactive injection and been sent home for 3 hours with dire warnings about not kissing babies or old people. I have to go back at midday for the scan which will take about an hour.  Karen, I don't think it's quite as in depth as the scan you had. There was a door with TEP on it and another with scintigraphy and I was taken through the scintigraphy one. They told me it's routine and just for bones as the CAT scan I had i hospital doesn't give enough info about bones. Apparently I can go back to work after -  I'm teaching a load of Doctors in the hospital anyway this afternoon so I'll just stagger from the scan to the classroom (perhaps via the café for a cuppa). Quite scary actually going down into the basement for  nuclear medicine  - when my Dad was in hospital a couple of years ago I often wondered when I got in the lift what was at -1 as there's no label. Now I know (unfortunately). Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Hi Lacomtekp I'm South West between Bordeaux and Toulouse. So good to find someone in France, I'd love to be involved in a bit of mutual cheering up. My surgeon is my Gynae, I don't know who the others are. I have an appointment with the psychologist in the cancer unit at the clinic tomorrow, there's a psychologist, a special nurse and an "assistante sociale" so hopefully will get some more info from them. I'd be very interested to hear about your treatment so far. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: I had one ovary and tube removed ten years ago - I had a burst appendix which went undiagnosed and it formed an abscess around my right ovary and tube which I then had to have removed. I had loads of bowel problems, including constipation and stomach cramps. It took a good 6 months for things to get back to to normal. Sarah
Posts.Title: Risk reducing surgery after BRCA1 positive result - concerns of symptoms...

Posts.Content: Hi Julia My K status is only 5% and I understand that anything under 10% is considered low, so I don't know whether I should have put positive for this.  I'm seeing  my surgeon tomorrow morning so hopefully will get a date with the oncologist - it feels like it's beginning to drag on a bit now, I just want to get on with it. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn I saw the surgeon yesterday and was signed off finally as I'm now all healed up although still black and blue after the scintigraphy. I have an appointment with the Oncologist on 28th April and an appointment for the pic line on 9th May. I asked the surgeon why I'm getting chemo when it's grade one and he said that it's because of the way the cancer was spreading and that fact that although there were only a few cells in one node, they were very much on the move and not particularly contained within the ganglion. I asked him about a prescription for a wig and he said not yet because the chemo I get may not make me lose my hair - I'm confused now as I thought everyone lost there hair.  Anyway I will ask the Oncologist the same question on 28th April . Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: Nope, absolutely no knickers allowed and the nasty blue tunic things that flap open at the back.
Posts.Title: Having a meltdown

Posts.Content: HI Yvonne How wonderful to be having your last chemo. As you say, you know exactly what to look out for now so it won't be too much of a shock if you do need help (hopefully you won't). Love Sarah
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: Hi Steph I've go 2 T left as well. How did the first one go for you?? Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: At least you're having some knickers, in France we have to go commando!!! :-)
Posts.Title: Having a meltdown

Posts.Content: Hello ladies Thanks Karen for this thread, I wholeheartedly agree that whilst it's important to know the list of potential side effects, it's also important to know that some of them are very rare indeed and I think I read somewhere that (correct me if I'm wrong) even the most common (apart from hair loss of course) affect less than 50% of people. It's easy to get into panic mode when facing the unknown and assume the worst, especially when others are having a terrible time. I have to say I panicked a bit about the tax; I had a horrible time on fec but so far (one week after first treatment) on tax I'm more than fine, in fact I'm considering starting to run again, I still have a yucky mouth but that's all, the aches were nothing, just slightly sore knees for a couple of days and my index finger nails are a bit sore, I have plenty of energy.  Karen, I am so happy that you're cancer free, hopefully the taste for cognac will back in time for Christmas. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hi Flopsy,  I really don't know for sure, as I say, it's just something I recall reading somewhere; my chemo nurse said "no nausea this time" as I left after my first tax and for me that was thankfully the case after terrible sickness with fec. Maybe the research was based on SE before the new generation of anti-nausea medication, I've had Emend all the way through which is hailed as a wonder drug although no help for me with the fec. Would be interesting to know if there's been more recent research. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hi Peartree I can't advise you on  whether it's safe to delay your radiotherapy, I have no idea but I completely understand your feelings about your holiday. I've just been told I have to have chemo (was hoping for just radiotherapy) and so I'm having to cancel my 50th birthday celebration holiday. I'm gutted and even wondered about refusing the chemo (it was borderline) because like you I've been looking forward to the holiday since September when it was booked. It's 3 weeks in Sri Lanka and India, so very hard to fit around any treatment.  But talking to the phsychologist I'm now reconciled to putting the holiday off for a year and having a belated 50th plus a celebration for my son finishing his baccalaureate, so maybe that's a possibility for you too if you can't put off the radiotherapy. Love Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: It's good news, it's a cyst, probably caused by the radiotherapy. They're going to leave it there unless it starts to cause me bother. So relieved and grateful to my fabulous consultant - I rang him at 10.30am and saw him at 2pm even though he's rushed off his feet, he got me in for a mammography/ultrasound at 8.15am the following morning, so by 9am I knew it was ok.  So so relieved, it came at a really difficult time, my mum was diagnosed with myeloma on the Friday, my husband had to dash back to the UK on the Saturday as his mum had a heart problem and was rushed into hospital and then on the Saturday evening, I discovered the lump. So at least one less thing to worry about now. Sarah
Posts.Title: Lump in breast 2 years after lumpectomy, chemo and radio

Posts.Content: Hi Gail, thanks for replying, I did post on here quite a lot when I was originally diagnosed in early 2016, it was an enormous help then which is why it's the first place I came for support and above all empathy. Sarah
Posts.Title: Lump in breast 2 years after lumpectomy, chemo and radio

Posts.Content: Hello, I had a lumpectomy 2 years ago followed by chemo and radio therapy. On saturday, I found a lump in my operated breast in the place that the original lump was removed from - I have hard scar tissue there and have been having physio to try and loosen it all up a bit, but there is a definite smooth hard round lump there. Doc is sending my for an ultrasound but I am terrified. My husband is away as his mother is ill so no one to talk too :-(
Posts.Title: Lump in breast 2 years after lumpectomy, chemo and radio

Posts.Content: Finally, I have my treatment plan so I can start looking forward. It's 6 cycles of chemo, 3 cycles of FEC and 3 of Taxotere, so fairly standard stuff, followed by 30 sessions of radiotherapy and then hormone therapy for 5 years. It all starts on 12th May.Not sure about the Oncologist, I'm used to my surgeon who knows me and is very up front about everything, I felt like he was talking down to me a little bit and I think he thought I was overly preoccupied with the wig- I had to ask him 3 times for the prescription and apparently, normally they don't give this until the first chemo appointment. But I don't want to wait, I want to have time to get used to it and be prepared. Anyway he gave it to me in the end. But he gave me loads of time and said that I should listen to my body and do whatever I want as long as I have the energy and not to worry if I don't, but not to have any expectations because everyone is different,  I have prescriptions for anti-nausea meds, an anaesthetic patch for my port-a -cath, transport to and from the clinic and a blood test which I have to have 48 hours before each session, oh and of course the wig. Going off tomorrow to have my hair chopped off - one of the perks of my job is free hair cuts/colour at the Chambre de Metiers hairdressing school in return for speaking English, so I'm going to give them a challenge (may even have it purple - it's only for a couple of weeks). Despite all the positive stuff, I've had a wobble today, I suppose it finally feels real and I've been inside the dreaded Oncology centre - I've driven past it every day for years and thanked my lucky stars I didn't have to go there - now I do. But hopefully by Christmas I'll be out the other side and looking forward to my postponed birthday holiday. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Treatment plan at long last

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn xxx
Posts.Title: Treatment plan at long last

Posts.Content: I loved your ramble Judy and particularly the advice about the Oncologist. He's probably right about the wig too, but I was just terrified about being bald and not having a wig ready. I get the wig 100% paid for and have been given a list of places to go, so I suppose I can shop around a bit, I have a bit of time.  Unfortunately I absolutely love my new haircut - I'd wanted to hate it so it falling out wouldn't have been such a problem, but hey ho - at least I have an idea for a shorter style when it's growing back and maybe I can get a wig in this style. I also felt a bit sad to be signed off by my surgeon who I've know for 13 years and feel safe with, so I suppose I was unfairly comparing the Oncologist to him. Actually I am sounding a bit wig obsessed. Will get stocked up on vaseline although I think I have some in the drawer left over from treating an egg bound chicken (although not sure I want it up my nose now. Good luck for Monday Love Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Treatment plan at long last

Posts.Content: Thanks Joellen Good luck with your reviewxxx
Posts.Title: Treatment plan at long last

Posts.Content: Brilliant news!!! Love Sarahxx
Posts.Title: 1st Annual mammo clear.....I am so happy

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian I'm in France too and as Karen says, we all get a portacath as standard. Mine is just under my collar bone on the right, it's painless and no dressings, no maintenance, just a flush through before and after the chemo drugs. The anaesthetic patch 1 hour before numbs it nicely so the needle doesn't hurt at all. I had mine put in under local and it was fine, the scar is barely noticable. Good luck tomorrow, it's so much easier when the first one is over. Sarahxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian I had horrible sickness for the first day with fec, I had my chemo on a Thursday morning and by Friday lunchtime I'd stopped vomiting and I suppose the nausea lasted for another day or two. After that I was fine and felt practically normal for the rest of the cycle. If you haven't had Emend ask for it because it is the best, unfortunately it didn't work for me but it seems to for a lot of people. It's good that you're drinking lots, it's hard sometimes but I really do think it helps the SEs pass a bit more quickly. The headache's pretty normal as well, I wasn't sure whether my headache was due to the fec or the vomiting, but it also passed after a few days. The important think is to rest now, take care of yourself. Lots of love Sarah
Posts.Title: Anyone had a Portacath in their arm? The one under the skin?

Posts.Content: Thanks Julie, Thanks for your reply, I've been really lucky with the speed of my treatment (it's actually 2.5 weeks from mammography), it's been fast even for France, I had mammogram on 24th Feb, biopsy on 25th, appointment with surgeon on 2nd March and surgery on 10th March. I should have final test results and treatment plan before I Ieave the hospital, hopefully on Tuesday. It's all good so far but my mind's just in overdrive about the rest of the tests, what if it's not a grade 1, what if it's in my lymph nodes after all, what if it's somewhere else? I'm driving myself nuts!! Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Thanks Julia, I've got Tom Sharpe's Indecent exposure in my bag (hubby brought it in for me). I've been frightened to get it about because it's got naked people on the front, but what the heck!! Sarah
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hi Julia Sorry, yes a ganglion is a lymph node, get my English and French muddled up sometimes. xx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: That's absolutely brilliant news Carolyn, so pleased for you. Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: I'm 49, I'm in France and 2 weeks ago at a routine mammography the doc found a mass. I had a biopsy the day after and here I am sitting in a hospital bed after a lumpectomy. Had blood tests today and a scan tomorrow. I carried on working for the two weeks and somehow put it to the back of my mind but being alone in hospital (private rooms in France) it's hit me that this isn't going to be a like a dose of the flu. I'd just assumed that I'd be back at work on Monday and life would continue as before. Life was just getting on track - I finally have enough work for us to live comfortably, 50th birthday celebration holiday to Sri Lanka booked for July, now there's this big question mark over it all. The cancer is small 8mm, looks contained and biopsy came back grade 1, doesn't look like it's spread to my lymph nodes as doc said yesterday morning everything is negative for the moment. But I'm in such a tizzy, I'm so happy to find this group, thanks for having mixx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Thanks Helen, It's very reassuring to hear from you. I've made the mistake of consulting Dr Google about the blood tests and the scan and the further analysis of the lump. I've got myself into a bit of a pickle, the hospital room is very nice but when visitors leave it's a bit lonely and every things happened so fast, it hadn't really sunk in until now. Anyway, I'll let you know how it goes. Sarah
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn Thanks for that, I am calmer and I do realise I've been very lucky to be diagnosed so early. Just about to leave hospital (without promised results) and I have an appointment with the consultant in 10 days to decide what happens next. I fell into the Google trap after the Mammogram as the doctor said nothing except for "I'll make an appointment for a biopsy" before dashing off. They wouldn't give me my dossier or any information before I left. I started reading about Bi-rads (acr in France), so I rang the clinic to ask for my Bi-rads and they told me it was 5. That's when the panic really set in  as I didn't know anything about the size of the tumour, so knowing that Bi-rads 5 means almost certainly cancer all sorts of terrible things began to go through my head. Luckily the biopsy was the next day and I found out that it was very small and didn't seem to have spread but I had 2 days of panic before a complete high and then normal life for a couple of weeks before the op. Anyway, back to as normal as possible for 10 days until the appointment.  Sarah
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Thanks Ann, Take care too, Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Went to see GP this morning and she'd received the pathology report for the lump. Nothing has changed so still grade 1 (hoorah) but it was found in 1 ganglion (6 removed) but very contained in the ganglion, so apparently there's going to be a meeting next week to decide what to do next. I don't appear to be invited to this which is a bit rubbish but then this is the downside of being in France - the upside being that everything happens really quickly and treatment is about need and not cost. GP says expect radio. So I suppose it's good news. Sarah
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Ah ok, so it's the same system really with regard to meetings, you're right there is only one thing worse than being talked about - my last post maybe sounded a bit ungrateful - typing without thinking!!! - I do realise I'm lucky with the care I'm getting but I suppose I've got a bit frustrated with having to chase around to get information. Sarahxx

Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hi, it's me again, I have managed by roundabout methods to obtain a photocopy of my biopsy report. I've got an appointment with my GP this Friday (as can't see the consultant until Friday 25th) but I can't wait. Can anyone help me a little bit with the results. It says: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Elston and Ellis grade 1. The following is a translation so hope it's right: oestrogen receptors: marking  2 to 90% of cells progesterone receptors - marking 2 to 80 % of cells Ki67: 5% HERCEPTEST 0+ Does this mean anything to anybody or is it lost in translation?? Sarahxxx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Carolyn and Julia, thank you so much. You have been the voices of reason and calm over the past few days, I do appreciate it. Carolyn, good luck with your radiotherapy. Sarahxx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, That's my worry really and why the next 10 days might be quite long!!! So for the moment keeping everything crossed. Sarah
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Good luck today Carolynxxxx
Posts.Title: Help!! Petrified.

Posts.Content: Hi Jen, I have had 2 fec and one ec delivered through a port and had no problems, I could feel a very mild burning sensation in my chest for a couple of days after each chemo but nothing more than this. I've been running on and off through chemo and no heart issues at all not even a palpitation. As a worrier myself, I would be inclined to discuss your worries with your oncologist or nurse I'm sure they'll be able to give you a more technical explanation as to why you shouldn't worry than I can. Love Sarahxx
Posts.Title: EC chemo through a portacath
